text: Robert McNeel what was the atmosphere
like in Dallas that day half a century
ago well at first it was delightful it
was a lovely sunny day and the Kennedys
came out of Air Force One resplendent
especially mrs. Kennedy in that
strawberry ice cream pink suit with her
hair glossy and glowing in the bright
sunshine and with a bunch of blood-red
roses
pressed up against her I was close
enough to mrs. Kennedy that I could look
over her shoulder and saw a hand to come
through the fence and break off one of
the roses she was carrying up till then
and through the outskirts of Dallas
crowds so thick and so milling out into
the street that from the first seat of
the press bus I could see over the other
cars in between it looked as though they
the street would be too crowded like a
river that's broken its banks for the
motorcade to get through that was the
atmosphere until we turned the corner
into Dealey Plaza now you were on the
press bus
what happened next there was a bang and
we all said to each other what was that
was such a shot and we had time for that
exchange and then there were two bangs
close together and I said those are
shots
stop the bus and then I thought I better
find a phone and the first building that
came to that looked as though it might
have a telephone where's the Texas
School Book Depository I ran up the
steps and as I did a young men in
shirtsleeves came out and I said where's
their phone and he said you better ask
inside and I did I did a bulletin about
the shots being fired people screaming
and the people lying down on the grass
covering their children with the bodies
people chasing up this grassy knoll and
saying it is not known if the shots were
directed at the president anyway I ran
outside and the policeman stopped me and
as he did a little black boy said to us
mister I seen a man with a gun right up
in the window there and another man came
up and said yes a man with a gun up
there and a woman ran up and said he
wasn't hurt was he and I and the
policeman said yes ma'am he was hurt bad
and then I learned that he'd been hit in
the head and taken to Parkland Hospital
did you meet Lee Harvey Oswald the
assassin that day I don't know
William Manchester insists that I did
and he quotes Oswald is mistaking me for
a secret serviceman apparently I would
have told the Secret Service that I
couldn't confirm it to Manchester when
he talked to me about it and in fact at
the Museum of the assassination in
Dallas they believe it was someone else
who household spoke to I can't prove it
it's it's titillating to think that I
might have asked him for the phone what
impact did covering the assassination
have on you personally during the
funeral I was standing at the grassy
knoll with a film crew and we were
filming the reactions of people who had
come to look at the few flowers and
notes that were left there the
beginnings were shrine and as we did an
elderly man came along with a transistor
radio and sat down beside us and at that
moment the Blackwatch highland pipe
regiment band passed the microphones in
the parade in Washington and the sound
of the bagpipes suddenly did something
to me and I was flooded with tears
actually sobbing there Robert McNeel
thank you so much for joining us for
those recollections it's a pleasure
thank you
